text.text_translated: During the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant that fewer children died young, which caused rapid population growth because these large families had more children who survived into adulthood. However, since contraception (methods used to prevent having a baby) became more widely available in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six to as low as two.
